text: here's the Finch hit hard the balls
hitting for the ball racing it down at
the centerfielder Eddie makes the catch
how he got to that is beyond me whoo
what a play every ballplayer is a
mathematician whether he knows it or not
that's because the key to catching a fly
ball is judging where it will land and
to do this a player must calculate the
vertical and lateral velocity of the
ball in fractions of a second
after contact it takes an outfielder a
half-second the detective the ball was
hit to the left
of course right
but if it's hit straight at him
trajectory of the ball won't be clear to
fall seconds
that's because balls hit 250 300 or 350
feet directly in an outfield will all
appear to have the same angle rise speed
and height changes are imperceptible
during the first second of flight and
with two seconds gone the outfielder has
less than three seconds to go before the
ball lands standing 300 feet from home
he doesn't have enough time to catch the
ball in front of him or the one hit over
his head so unless he factors in other
clues this job would be next to
impossible
an experienced outfielder who watches
the pitch examines the batter's swing
and listens for the crack of the bat to
determine where he needs to be in
fractions of a second these observations
are processed and match to past
experiences giving him the time he needs
to make the catch
so experiments trumps any magic formula
batching the ball until it's safely in
his glove the player must continually
recalculate his path to the ball and
determine when and where to stick out
his glove to make the catch
so in reality the laws of physics may
help you understand how a ball will fly
but only practice can help you figure
out where it will land
